text: To carry on the business of the people. When the Constitution was being framed, the States took care to to us many services that could not be made self-supporting. They were prepared to hand over to the' Commonwealth all that gave no result, and there is now, apparently, a " little game on " to relieve the States of some more of their expenditure. These public buildings are necessary for the convenience of the people, and it is unreasonable for the people concerned to ask us to make the roads leading up to them. It would be just as reasonable to ask the Commonwealth to make the footpaths leading to the post-offices in our towns and cities as it is to urge that we should make the roads leading to other Commonwealth buildings.

Speaker: Mr CANN
Title: COMMONWEALTH CONTROL
text: Why should not the Commonwealth do so?

Speaker: Mr SPENCE
Title: COMMONWEALTH CONTROL
text: I have never heard of any argument in favour of the adoption of such a course, unless we are to socialize all the roads, and to have a complete Socialistic community. Whilst I believe that local government has done a vast amount of good work, I do not think any case can be made out for this demand. The honourable member for Maribyrnong has himself proved the case that I was going to put before the Committee, namely, that in this instance it is proposed to reverse the system under which municipal subsidies are paid by the States. Under that system the city municipalities receive practically 0 nothing, whereas the shires receive a subsidy amounting, in some cases, to £ 3 on every £ 1 locally raised. Such a grant is considered necessary to open up new country. The proposal which the honourable member for Maribyrnong is supporting is not based upon that principle. Property in towns and cities is worth far more than are country properties, so that the adoption of this proposal would mean that the biggest proportion of the grant would be paid to the municipalities that least required it. While the honourable member for Corangamite was speaking, the honourable member for Perth interjected that the residents of the cities were paying for the postal accommodation enjoyed by country districts. The honourable member is absolutely wrong. I do not desire to traverse the ground already covered by the honourable member for Corangamite, whose arguments were unanswerable, but I would remind the honourable member for Perth that the cities exist only because of the backing they receive from the country districts. Cities and towns consist of groups of business people, and also, in the case of cities like Melbourne and Sydney, of manufacturers. Where is their market? In the country. Their correspondence is paid for by the country consumers. The farmer pays freight on what he buys and on what he sells. It is he who is charged for the cost of running the railways, and the interest on the money borrowed for their construction. He also pays the rents of the city business firms, and the expenses of their correspondence. It is the man in the country who pays, and the man in the city goes scot-free. I could mention facts which tell against the proposal even more strongly than those adduced by the honourable member for Corangamite. Only yesterday, for instance, the residents of a shire in my district, far removed from the big cities, asked for telephone connection, and were told that they could have it if they supplied £250 worth of material. This they are going to do, I believe. According to the arguments of those who support the motion, the shire council in which the line is to be constructed should be paid a subsidy for having the poles along its roads. If we agree to this proposal, the Commonwealth will be expected to make [95] good the wear of country roads caused by mail coaches, and there will be no limit to the demands on it. I do not think that the House will be foolish enough to agree to the motion. Municipal councils, like other .bodies, look upon the Government as a sort of milch cow. They consider us good-natured people, from whom they can get money. In my eyes this proposal is an attempt to relieve the States of the duty of assisting the municipal authorities. The honourable member for Maribyrnong spoke about the high valuations. These would mean a very large sum out of the Commonwealth purse for city properties, if we were to make ourselves responsible for rates. At the present time, the State Treasurers are cutting down their expenditure, and if we subsidized the municipalities, the State Governments would decrease their subsidies, so that the municipalities would really be no better off. It must be borne in mind that we have no control over municipal authorities. We are not responsible for their constitutions. Tbeir franchise has a Conservative basis, which no Labour man could support, it being founded on a property qualification. We cannot subsidize bodies over which we have no control. Only two instances have been mentioned in which special damage has been done to roads by the traffic to Commonwealth factories, and it would be foolish to subsidize all municipalities because of those two special cases. To say that £50,000 would be sufficient is absurd. In the big cities there are post-offices every block or two, although in the country postal facilities are not easily obtainable, and there are people in my electorate who pay £ 1 5 and £ 2 0 a year to get their letters forwarded. In the cities the people will not walk a quarterof-a-mile to post a letter, and there are so many post-offices, and other Commonwealth buildings, that £50,000 would not cover the rating for one State alone. It must be remembered that in the future several big industries will be nationalized, and the Commonwealth will then own huge factories. It would be a nice thing to have to pay rates on that property, which might be worth millions of pounds. I should not oppose, on the ground of cost, a proposal which I considered just, but this is not a just proposal. We are here to protect the public purse, and, in view of the charge of extravagance which has been made against thi.s Government, I am surprised that some Ministerial supporters favour the proposal. Of course, one cannot be surprised at anything that the Opposition may do. If they can increase the troubles of the - ment, they will gain a party advantage. I - am aware that the Municipal Association has circularized honourable members with a view to getting a subsidy. For this it is not to blame, but it is none the less our duty to study the public interest. I agree with the honourable member for Corangamite that public bodies should not tax each other, seeing that they all work for the common good. The municipalities have done good work in Australia, though they have yet to take up questions which are handled by the municipal authorities in the Old World; but their ratepayers would not benefit if this proposal were carried into effect, because, even if there were a reduction in rates, there' would have to be an crease in taxes, and if the Commonwealth gave a subsidy, the State Governments would reduce their subsidies. No case has been made out for the motion.

Speaker: Mr HARPER
Title: COMMONWEALTH CONTROL
text: Mernda) [7.45] - I listened to the Budget-speech of the Prime Minister with very great disappointmenta feeling created by the fact that I expected the honourable gentleman to take this opportunity, in the last session of this Parliament, to take the House and the country into his confidence by a clear and - definite exposition of the financial policy of the Government. I think that was due to members on both sides of the House, even to those who are supporting the Government. The - occasion was so important, and the interests - so great, that the fullest and clearest exposition was expected from, and should have been afforded by, the Treasurer. Instead of a Budget-speech, we had - simply a long statement. It lacked - every quality which a Budget-speech ought to have. There was hardly a reference to .the previous year; no attempt to bring the minds of honourable members what the course of finance had been during that year, by calling our attention to the amounts which the Treasurer had estimated to receive at the beginning of the year, the amounts he had received; the amounts which he had anticipated to expend during the year, and the amounts he had expended, to explain the sources of the excess of revenue and expenditure. These facts could have been given, with some clear - exposition, which need not have been lengthy, to put honourable members en rapfort with the position and bring it up to - date. Certainly, from the somewhat awkward way in which the Budget statement was introduced, it was very difficult for any honourable member to quite follow the Treasurer. A feeling of disappointment in that regard was exhibited on his own side of the House. I think, through hurry, or for some other reason which I cannot explain the Treasurer had not prepared himself, and we were, therefore, all left to find out for ourselves, as we best could, the real meaning of his statements. If he had told us what he might have told us, we should have learnt from him that last year he. expected to receive £19,515,000, and actually received £20,546,361, or a surplus over his estimate of £1,031,361. The expenditure he - estimated at £19,515,000, and he actually expended £20,121,995. That is to say, he received £1,031,361 more than he expected, and spent £606,995 more than he anticipated, with the net result that he had a balance on the year's operations of £424,366, which he appropriated under a method that has lately been adopted of putting moneys into Trust Funds. That sum was placed to the credit [95]- 2 of Trust Funds in the proportion of £278,242 to the Fleet Fund, and £146,124 to the Pensions Fund. That was the position when we started the year, and it revealed to us that we had had a second prosperous year since the present Government came into office, and that, although the balance was not so large as in the previous year, it was still substantial, and had gone to the credit of Trust Funds, to be dealt with as I shall show later on. Having initiated the business and shown us where we were, we had a right to expect the Prime Minister to explain, on behalf of the Government, what his financial proposals were for dealing with the before great engagements which the Commonwealth has undertaken; but we did not get one word of explanation. Honourable members will recollect that on the Address-in-Reply I raised the question of the large commitments of the Commonwealth, and asked how the Government proposed to meet the obligations which would accrue therefrom. My remarks were received with a good deal of interjection and objection, as if I were objecting to the expenditure; but I clearly showed on that occasion that then, at any rate, I was not objecting to the expenditure, but was asking the Government to tell Parliament and' the country how they intended to find the money. I was followed by the Postmaster-General, who, having acted for six months when the Treasurer was away, might have been supposed to know something of the subjects to which I had alluded, and, being the Minister to follow, might naturally have been expected to give some information. Instead of that, he asked a series of questions: " What would the honourable member do? Does he object to old-age pensions? Does he object to defence ? Does he object to this, that, and ,the other?" As a matter of fact ' it was the merest "gag," and had no reference to the subject. It was simply a means of putting me off with the appearance of giving an answer, while giving no answer at all. The Postmaster-General, when I repeatedly asked where the money was to come from, said that the Prime Minister would tell the House, and, later, that the Prime Minister would give the information in his Budget. I am here to-night to say that not on one single point I then raised, and on which I was promised an answer in the Budget, have I received any information. I do not think that is treating serious business in the way it should be treated. This is not, or should not, be a matter of party; it is one that concerns honourable members in all parts of the House, and for the consequences of our action at this stage we shall rightly be held responsible. To-night it is my intention, so far as I am permitted to discharge my obligation, to place before the Committee and the Government the position of our financial affairs as it appears to me, with the object that, whatever the consequences may be by-and-by, we shall know to what the state of things, which may exist, is owing.

text: Bendigo) [9.21] The Committee must be under a great obligation to the honourable member for Mernda for his able, comprehensive, and moderate survey of the financial position. In matters of finance, which involve a considerable amount of special knowledge, I think that the honourable member is entitled to a little consideration, and I regret that he was not allowed to complete his speech. The refusal to allow him to continue beyond the time allotted by the Standing Orders has taken us by surprise, and I feel somewhat at a disadvantage in continuing the debate after his unfinished but masterly speech. I cannot hope to make an analysis of the financial features of the Budget in the same critical and searching manner; but that, perhaps, is hardly necessary, in view of the ground already covered. I think it might be convenient to premise a few remarks of a practical character on the Budget by some general observations regarding the conditions under which the financial statement has been presented. This is the third, and, for this Parliament, the last of a series of three financial statements submitted by the present Treasurer during a period of unparalleled prosperity, in the history of Commonwealth. I cannot but congratulate him and his colleagues on the. good fortune they have enjoyed in being in office and in power with a big majority behind them during such a glorious period of prosperity'. Although this has been, apparently, a brilliant financial period, judging from some stand-points of history, there are other features hardly consistent with a period of prosperity, and the promises and policy of the Prime Minister and his colleagues. I should like, in a few sentences, to contrast some of the phases of this period of Labour rule. On the one hand there have been increased imports of merchandise, a larger revenue, higher salaries, more work in the Public Service,larger expenditure, an expansion of Government functions and of opportunities for political patronage; on the other there have been unsatisfactory features requiring consideration and explanation. There has been a remarkable reduction in our exports and in the production of gold, the cost of living has increased, money has become dearer, the power of the banks to give accommodation has been diminished, and the industrial unrest has been remarkable. We were promised that under Labour rule wages would rise and employment increase, but there have been more strikes since this Government took office than in any other similar period of our history. During the last three years no fewer than 220 strikes were recorded in the various States. I gave particulars concerning them on a former occasion, and shall not repeat what I said then. This industrial unrest is in striking contrast to the prosperity which the country has enjoyed. A most extraordinary position was revealed by the deputation which a few weeks ago the Leader of the Opposition in the Parliament of Victoria introduced to the Premier of the State. It complained that there are some 2,000 Victorian artisans now out of work, most of them agricultural implement makers, iron and metal workers, clothing and textile workers, and machinists. An account of the deputation appeared in the Age of the n t h July, not long before the delivery of this extraordinary Budget, which discovered a larger revenue and expenditure than we had ever before known in Australia. Evidently the picture, presented with such self-glorification by the Prime Minister, has its reverse side. There is something needing explanation. We were not told why, in the midst the of so much activity and prosperity, there should be such dissatisfaction in the ranks of the working classes. We must be thankful for the prosperity we have enjoyed, ancl glad that the country has so greatly progressed, and must hope that the evils to which I have referred will in time disappear. Apparently we are now on the crest of the wave of prosperity, ancl two lines the Budget show that the Treasurer expects the revenue from Customs and Excise to decline, a sign-no t greater than a man's hand in the sky, perhaps-that unfavorable developments are approaching. I am afraid that there may be some justification for the apprehension of the honourable member for Mernda that less prosperous times may shortly be upon us. One of the characteristics of the period ot Labour rule has been the increased cost of living, and the higher price of money. Notwithstanding the inflation of revenue and expenditure, money is not so abundant as it was; it is not so cheap to those who require financial accommodation. Plainly, the Labour party has not fulfilled'its promise to give us cheaper money and to reduce the cost of living. We were told that, when the Commonwealth Bank had been established and the Australian notes issued, money would be plentiful and - cheap; but one of the immediate results of the note issue has been to raise the of discount and to increase the price of money. Careful consideration of the facts shows that the note issue has not realized the hopes held forth on its account. About 4,000,000 sovereigns are locked up in the vaults of the Treasury as a reserve against the note issue. That gold is idle. It has been withdrawn from circulation, andno longer earns interest; and its withdrawal has reduced the credit of the Commonwealth. A gold reserve is essential to the note system; but the result of the withdrawal of gold from circulation is a reduction of credit. Under the old system, the banks could have lent out the money to the borrowing public; now the necessity is imposed on them of keeping a certain number of Commonwealth notes in their coffers, to be used as till-money. For these notes the banks have paid sovereigns, and have thus diminished their lending power. The statement in the speech delivered some time ago by the honourable member for Mernda, and the evidence of all financial experts, is that the effect of the note issue has been to diminish the financial power of the tanks, to force them to compel their customers to reduce their overdrafts. To that extent it has interfered with the industrial expansion of the Commonwealth, and the business operations of many people in it. I do not say it is the sole factor, but it is undoubtedly one of the factors in which account for the financial depression of the.times, and which have to be remembered when credit is claimed for the note issue. The Prime Minister claimed that he had realized about £184,000 net interest on the balance which had been lent to the States and other institutions from the note issue fund. After allowing a certain amount for the expenses of the issue, he said the net profit would be only about £143,000.

In another passage he saysInstances have occurred where irregularities of a serious nature in respect to employment have been reported, and where persons who have never even complied with the provisions of the Act, as to registration, have been placed on the Temporary Staff. In one State four men were engaged by the Department in this way, and, when it is stated that two of these persons were considered to be ineligible for registration, owing to previous bad records when in the permanent employ of the Department, the gravity of the position is apparent. These cases were reported to the Auditor-General, and it is probable that the officers responsible for the irregularity be surcharged the amount of salary which has been illegally paid to the temporary hands.

Speaker: Mr JH CATTS
Title: COMMONWEALTH CONTROL
text: That is not Ministerial.

Speaker: Sir JOHN QUICK
Title: COMMONWEALTH CONTROL
text: I am saying that that shows the necessity for an amendment of the law to regulate the employment of temporary hands in a definite way, and to prevent the exercise of either political or departmental patronage. Even in the employment of men to do temporary work, or exempt hands, we should insist upon their undergoing some test to show their efficiency. We should not let them be put on as an act of favour or patronage. The complaint of the Public Service Commissioner is that even persons required for temporary purposes are put on without regard to efficiency, and very often without regard to registration.

Speaker: Mr THOMAS
Title: COMMONWEALTH CONTROL
text: If you wanted a man for telephone tunnelling, what examination would you expect him to go through ?

Speaker: Sir JOHN QUICK
Title: COMMONWEALTH CONTROL
text: The Commissioner suggests that the Department might have a recognised system of choice and selection to determine efficiency. He saysI am far from satisfied that the heavy expenditure during.the past year is justified'fro m any stand-point, bearing in mind the large additions to the Permanent Staff of officers in the two principal States, and this view is strengthened by the many instances which have come within my notice of irregularities, for which there can be no satisfactory explanation. That is our own Commissioner reporting to the House irregularities for which there is no satisfactory explanation. In another part he saysIt has apparently not been recognised that, in conferring a favour upon applicants who were in a position to exert influenceThere is a distinct allusion to the exercise of influence.

Speaker: Mr JH CATTS
Title: COMMONWEALTH CONTROL
text: Socia l influence.

Speaker: Sir JOHN QUICK
Title: COMMONWEALTH CONTROL
text: I do not care whether it is social or political, the Commissioner refers to the fact that influence is being exertedan injustice is at the same time being inflicted on deserving men who have relied upon securing a share of temporary work in their proper order - f registration.

Speaker: Mr MCWILLIAMS
Title: COMMONWEALTH CONTROL
text: Are they not put on in their order of registration?

Speaker: Sir JOHN QUICK
Title: COMMONWEALTH CONTROL
text: The Commissionerreports that, although there is a book in the office presided over by him for the registration of applications for employment, men are being put on without reference to will the employment register by departmental officers.

Speaker: Mr MCWILLIAMS
Title: COMMONWEALTH CONTROL
text: That is not fair.

Speaker: Sir JOHN QUICK
Title: COMMONWEALTH CONTROL
text: It is a breach of the law. It is time that Ministers insisted upon the enforcement of the law in reference to temporary employment; but there is a still more insidious way of evading the provisions of the Public Service Act requiring qualifications for service. That is by withdrawing certain classes of employment altogether from the Act, under the term of "exempt employment." In this report, which was made last November, the Commissioner refers to some things that were news to me, and I think will be news to a number of honourable members. He saysAction has been taken during the past few years to specially exempt classes of employee's such as casual letter-carriers, postal assistants, telephonists, and telegraph messengers in country districts; casual messengers in metropolitan districts; linemen, labourers, and tradesmen employed outside metropolitan areas; - labourersand mechanics employed in conduit work; watchmen and navvies engaged on underground cable work, &c. Those make a large group of men actually exempt from the ordinary operations of the Public Service Act. Their employment is vested in departmental heads, without any conditions or regulations, or any mode of choice being determined. It is a mere matter of favour, influence, and pressure brought to bear. I am just as much against departmental patronage as against political influence. It might, perhaps, be more objectionable, and therefore I think aU this group of employees ought to be withdrawn from departmental influence. Why should men be dependent for employment as letter-carriers, tradesmen, mechanics, & c , on departmental officers, overseers, or superintendents ? There ought to be a recognised method of registration, and certain defined qualifications for a man who wants to obtain employment of this kind. The work might be temporary, or, if it is exempt employment, it might even be permanent, and it certainly should not depend on the ipse dixit, favour, or preference of anybody. There should be a regular standard of choice and mode of selection, as recommended by the Minister himself. If honourable members will support their own Commissioner in a proposition of that kind, it will be a great relief to themselves. It will save their being called upon to exercise influence either on Ministers or officers to get work of a temporary or exempt character. I do not think that anything is to be gained by members of Parliament in being bothered by employment questions. It is best to allow them to be determined by certainregular tribunals authorized by law. When men require either temporary or exempt billets, they ought to comply with, certain conditions, and fulfil certain requirements, and be able to get the work without fear, favour, or affection. The Commissioner's summary isIt will be seen from the above rlsumi of the conditions governing temporary and exempted employment, Uiat under the present unsatisfactory methods of regulating the selection and appointment of persons for this class of work, the inducements for the exercise of pressure in securing Government employment are very considerable. Those are the representations of a statutory officer appointed by Parliament. They are, I think, of sufficient weight to command the attention of the House. They should constrain honourable members to insist upon an amendment of the law to provide for an improved method of determining the conditions and qualifications, of service, and an improved mode of choice in all branches of Commonwealth employment.
